start.speaker: Kade
start.text: Ever heard of the DRY pricniple? To avoid writing the same code over and over, we let computers handle repetitive tasks through loops.

intro.speaker: Kade
intro.text: A loop is a programming tool that allows developers to repeat the same block of code until some condition is met.

type.speaker: Kade
type.text: There are 3 types of loops: a while loop, a for loop and a for-each loop.

for.speaker: Kade
for.text: The basic structure is this: for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { }. The variable i is first initialised at 0, and incremented by 1 each loop. The loop continues until the condition i < 5 is no longer true (i.e. after the fifth loop).

each.speaker: Kade
each.text: For-each loops, on the other hand, are used when we loop iterable collections, especially when we do not care about the index, only the element itself. Let's now try for-each loops, using for (int i : List.of(1,2,3)) { }!
